Step 4: Output the summarized chunk Continuing appropriations are provided if regular appropriation bills for a fiscal year are not passed before the fiscal year begins. Funds are allocated from the Treasury or other revenues to continue projects or activities from the previous fiscal year. Appropriations and funds for projects or activities in a fiscal year under this section are limited to the rate of operations from the previous fiscal year's regular appropriation Act or the rate set by this section. These funds are available from the start of the fiscal year until the regular appropriation bill becomes law. Appropriations and funds for projects or activities in a fiscal year under this section are subject to terms and conditions from the previous fiscal year. Expenditures for a project or activity during the applicable fiscal year are covered by the appropriations, funds, or authority granted. Expenditures for projects or activities in a fiscal year are charged to the appropriate appropriation when a regular appropriation bill becomes law. No appropriation is made for projects without authorization. This section does not apply if other laws provide funding or authority for the project. The regular appropriation bill defines categories of projects and activities for which funds are allocated, including agriculture, rural development, defense, and activities in the District of Columbia. No funds can be made available without authorization, and projects must be charged to the appropriate appropriation when a regular appropriation bill becomes law. The regular appropriation bill allocates funds for various activities chargeable against the revenues of the District, including departments like Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, Housing and Urban Development, Energy and water development, Foreign assistance, Military construction, Transportation, Treasury Department, U.S. Postal Service, and the legislative branch. Chapter 13 of title 31, United States, is also analyzed. The analysis of chapter 13 of title 31, United States Code, is amended by inserting a new item after section 1310. Continuing appropriations amendments apply to fiscal years after September 30, 1993. Point of order against continuing resolutions in the House and Senate, can be waived in the Senate with a three-fifths vote. Appeal of ruling requires a three-fifths vote. An appeal of a ruling in the Senate shall be limited to two hours, divided between the majority and minority leaders or their designees, and not subject to a motion to table.
